author: Charlotte Mathews
title: Switch to renewables can benefit municipalities | Energy
text:
Picture: REUTERS Related articles Green energy needs more black owners in future, says state Britain’s nuclear folly a lesson for SA Ten more independent power bidders get the nod Gas to become key electricity source, says Joemat-Pettersson Gas must play big role in SA energy mix — Econometrix report Renewable energy is SA’s solution In this article JSE-listed companies: EOH Companies and organisations: South African Chamber of Commerce and Industry MUNICIPALITIES should not see the move of customers towards their own electricity generation through renewables and co-generation as a revenue loss but as an opportunity for new revenue streams, EON Consulting MD Bertha Dlamini said on Monday.
Eskom’s shortage of electricity to meet demand has hit municipalities, for which selling electricity is a major source of income.
According to Rob Surtees, the MD of Enerweb, a subsidiary of EOH, peak demand in SA in 2011 was 36,200 MW. In the past winter it was 32,000MW, a reflection not only of demand management and energy efficiency but also lack of supply.
Ms Dlamini told the Association of Municipal Electricity Utilities (AMEU) conference in Sandton that municipalities could be more creative in diversifying their revenue, for example, by offering households hire purchase agreements for rooftop solar panels or energy efficiency solutions such as double glazing.
"It is time for a new operating model for municipalities," she said.
Other speakers discussed the opportunities for municipalities to commission their own renewable power generation. They said there was a need for changes in legislation, including the Municipal Finance Management Act, to provide certainty to private sector power providers by enabling municipalities to sign long-term power purchase agreements.
Silas Zimu, a special adviser to the president on energy, said the current act did not prevent municipalities from signing long-term agreements, as long as it was on the basis of a decision taken by a mayoral council.
He said metropolitan authorities did not need to rely on the Treasury to provide funding for renewable energy projects since development finance institutions were willing to do so.
Chris Yelland, the MD of EE Publishers, said the private sector had to be brought in to help with power projects. In the same period that private companies had added 1,600MW of renewable power to the grid, Eskom had added only 100MW.
Dave Long, an adviser to Business Unity SA, said the tariffs had to be acceptable. The National Energy Regulator of SA’s approved tariff was an average including old and new power generation assets, whereas developers needed a tariff that reflected the costs of new generation.
Peggy Drodskie, the chief operating officer of the South African Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said this was a point made by chamber members, and it should be noted that private developers were taking risk and could not rely on bailouts.
Dennis Mokoala, an assistant manager of energy services at Polokwane municipality, called on the AMEU to approach the Department of Energy for funding to assist municipalities to deal with load shedding. He said municipalities incurred costs from load shedding, including loss of revenue, more overtime, crime and more frequent maintenance.
In Polokwane, overtime costs had increased by R120,000 a month because of load shedding while it had had to spend R750,000 on maintaining its switchgear annually rather than every three years.
Another R1.2m had to be spent on repairing cables between April and July as load shedding exposed weak points, Mr Mokoala said.
